title: Beloved Port Orchard grandmother killed by hit-and-run driver
text:
The son of a beloved Kitsap County wife and grandmother killed last week wants the man or woman responsible to come forward.
“Whoever that is,” Marcus Lukkasson said. “My mom was a forgiving person, but responsibility is a civilized thing.”
Investigators with the Washington State Patrol believe 64-year-old Christopher Lukkasson, known as “Chris,” was struck by a hit-and-run driver as she walked along Victory Drive Southwest, just outside her home.
Nearly one week later, that driver still has not been identified.
“I’m going to miss her dearly,” her husband of 47 years, Mark Lukkasson, said on Tuesday.
He and his wife were married while still in high school—and lived together in their Port Orchard home for nearly 50 years, where they raised their son and daughter, who still live nearby.
“She was the most caring person I’ve ever known,” daughter Jennifer Lukkasson Crider said. “She’s my best friend.”
“My mom was this family,” 41-year-old Marcus Lukkasson added. “She’s the reason we’re still holding it together, because of the way she raised us.”
Flowers mark the side of the road where Lukkasson was found, unconscious and gravely injured mid-day last Wednesday.
She was airlifted to Harborview Medical Center, where she later died.
Investigators with the Washington State Patrol believe Lukkasson was struck while on her daily walk through the Sunnyslope neighborhood.
Trooper Mark Hodgson said evidence found at the scene is being processed and investigators are tracking down leads.
They’re also canvasing the area for any surveillance video that could help identify the suspect and his or her vehicle.
“Whoever has done this, I hope you have a heavy heart right now,” Lukkasson’s 43-year-old daughter said, outside of the family home.
“Claim responsibility,” her brother added. “Let God invade your heart. Please, come forward.”
Anyone with information about the incident should contact the Washington State Patrol.
